(1) http://example.com/resource
(2) http://example.com/resource;view=3Dedit=
 (or ?action=3Dedit, same difference)

These are considered "arbitrarily di=
fferenct URIs" as explained here:

http://www.w3.org/TR/webarch/#uri-aliase=
s

That's a "should not" not a "must not", though.  The /resource;view=3Ded=
it and /resource;view=3Dprint representations are, for all intents and purp=
oses, separate resources which are considered separate from /resource.  Wha=
t is needed is a means to describe the relationship of both /resource;view=
=3Dedit and /resource;view=3Dprint to be the same as /resource, removing th=
e ambiguity (and thus the negative effects) of the URI alias.

This is easy=
 enough to do from a pragmatic standpoint by adding this line to the <head>=
 of ;view=3Dedit and ;view=3Dprint:

<meta name=3D"ROBOTS" content=3D"NOIND=
EX,NOFOLLOW"/>

A legitimate search engine, i.e. Google, would otherwise re=
turn /resource, /resource;view=3Dprint *and* /resource;view=3Dedit in the r=
esults for a search which hits on /resource.  This keeps us from running af=
oul of the duplicate removal algorithms and getting "scored down" for SEO s=
henanigans with our intended aliases.  This is also done for the ;view=3Dpr=
int representation.

Unfortunately, this solution is lacking from a semanti=
c standpoint.  I've not yet delved into RDFa, but I hear I can describe URI=
 (1) to be the "same as" URI (2) to remove any ambiguity caused by the URI =
alias.

So by doing both of these things, our edit-form and print-page "int=
ended aliases" do no harm.  This is why I suggest the term "pseudo-resource=
" for the common use cases of edit forms and print pages.

(1) http://examp=
le.com/resource;view=3Dxhtml
(2) http://example.com/resource;view=3Dhtml

T=
hese are meant as representations only, not as individual resources.  They =
could just as easily be resource.xhtml and resource.html, either way we hav=
e an alias problem since each representation is, for all intents and purpos=
es, separate resources which are separate from /resource.

But, this is onl=
y true if (1) and (2) respond with a 200 OK!  My implementation 303-redirec=
ts (1) and (2) (and also ;view=3Dtext, come to think of it) to /resource th=
ereby removing the ambiguity and negating the alias.  Since (1) and (2) may=
 not be dereferenced they are only URIs not URLs, as per:

http://www.w3.or=
g/2001/tag/issues.html#httpRange-14

Although I'm afraid the group may agre=
e that I've gotten that wrong somehow, I haven't gone mad yet, Mark.  ;-)

=
Under my scheme, spiders only index the /resources on the system not the al=
iases, and always index the text-only version (my preference not to allow i=
mage indexing).  A user following a search-result link never gets the ;view=
=3Dedit page, but always gets content-negotiated into the (most) proper rep=
resentation for their client.

I've also toyed with having /resource;view=
=3Dedit 303-redirect to /resource.  This works, but it lacks the ability to=
 "back out of" (except by following a link) which isn't important for toggl=
ing between XHTML/HTML (which assumes the user knows what they're doing).  =
From a usability perspective, I'd prefer the ability to back out of the ;vi=
ew=3Dprint and ;view=3Dedit options by either using the back function on th=
e client or shortening the URL, in addition to being able to click a breadc=
rumb link.

The only way I know of to make that work, is to allow those two=
 aliases to respond 200 OK and mitigate the effects.

-Eric
